dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: ...so wait, five days off, you said, for Nauryz? I thought it was just like, a weekend thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...so wait, five days off, you said, for Nauryz? I thought it was just like, a weekend thing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, no, um, it's actually three core days, the 21st to the 23rd, but because of how the calendar, uh, falls...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, no, um, it's actually three core days, the twenty first to the twenty third, but because of how the calendar, uh, falls...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In March, Kazakhstanis celebrate the most important holiday of spring - Nauryz, in honor of which everyone rests for three days - from March 21 to 23.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like, this year? Or next year? I'm already lost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like, this year? Or next year? I'm already lost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so this past year, I mean, when the article was written, the 21st to 23rd hit a weekend, so they got five days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so this past year, I mean, when the article was written, the twenty first to twenty third hit a weekend, so they got five days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since this year the holidays fall on weekends, with a five-day work week, Kazakhstanis will rest for five days.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Ohhh, so like, they rolled over?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ohhh, so like, they rolled over?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then for 2025, itâ€™s even clearer. The 21st to 23rd are Friday, Saturday, Sunday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then for twenty twenty five, it's even clearer. The twenty first to twenty third are Friday, Saturday, Sunday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2025, holidays fall on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday, so the weekend is moved to March 24 and 25 (Monday and Tuesday).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Which means... Monday and Tuesday off?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which means... Monday and Tuesday off?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, precisely. March 24th and 25th become official days off, too. So another five days.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, precisely. March twenty fourth and twenty fifth become official days off, too. So another five days.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2025, holidays fall on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday, so the weekend is moved to March 24 and 25 (Monday and Tuesday).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So what is Nauryz anyway? Like, why is it such a big deal?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So what is Nauryz anyway? Like, why is it such a big deal?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it's huge. It's their, um, most important spring holiday. It means "new day" in Persian.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it's huge. It's their, um, most important spring holiday. It means new day in Persian.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In March, Kazakhstanis celebrate the most important holiday of spring - Nauryz... Its name translated from Persian means "new day", and the traditions of the celebration go back centuries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: New day? Like, a new year?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: New day? Like, a new year?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! It's the start of the new year on the Eastern calendar, symbolizing nature's renewal, spring's arrival.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! It's the start of the new year on the Eastern calendar, symbolizing nature's renewal, spring's arrival.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nauryz symbolizes the renewal of nature, the arrival of spring, and the beginning of the new year according to the Eastern calendar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so it's like a spring cleaning, new beginnings kind of thing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so it's like a spring cleaning, new beginnings kind of thing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. People clean their homes, throw out old stuff, uh, forgive offenses. And they eat this special soup, Nauryz kozhe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. People clean their homes, throw out old stuff, uh, forgive offenses. And they eat this special soup, Nauryz kozhe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Before the holiday, it is customary to clean the house, throw out old things, and forgive offenses. And the main dish of the holiday is nauryz kozhe, a soup made from seven ingredients symbolizing prosperity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Seven ingredients, symbolizing prosperity. Plus, there are concerts, games, fairs... it's a huge celebration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seven ingredients, symbolizing prosperity. Plus, there are concerts, games, fairs... it's a huge celebration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And the main dish of the holiday is nauryz kozhe, a soup made from seven ingredients symbolizing prosperity. Concerts, sports games, fairs, and theatrical performances are held in cities and villages.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: And the president got involved, with the Nauryznama thing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the president got involved, with the Nauryznama thing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, in 2024, they approved a new, multi-day format for Nauryznama, making it even bigger, more cultural.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, in twenty twenty four, they approved a new, multi-day format for Nauryznama, making it even bigger, more cultural.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The new format of the celebration, approved in 2024 on the initiative of President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, makes Nauryz multi-day and full of cultural events.
